title: Natalie Roston
text: I am passionate about creating user-centric experiences and products that solve real-world problems. With a focus on empathy, I have worked on a variety of collaborative projects that have allowed me to continuously expand the boundaries of my heuristics. I invite you to explore some of my work in the “projects” tab and see how I have applied my skills to create impactful designs.

title: World Heritage Sites
text:
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2024-02-06')
heritage <- tuesdata$heritage

library(tidyr)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyverse)
data_long <- heritage %>%
     pivot_longer(cols = c(`2004`, `2022`), names_to = "year", values_to = "value")
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data_long, aes(x = year, y = value, color = country, group = country)) +
     geom_line(size = 1) +
     geom_point(size = 3) +
     labs(title = "Country Values in 2004 and 2022",
          x = "Year",
          y = "Value") +
     scale_color_manual(values = c("Norway" = "blue", "Denmark" = "red", "Sweden" = "green")) +
     theme_minimal()








Sources:
Data Science Learning Community (2024). Tidy Tuesday: A weekly social data project. https://tidytues.day
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2024/2024-02-06
https://whc.unesco.org/en/list

title: Refugees
text:
library(dplyr)

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2023-08-22')
population <- tuesdata$population
desired_variables <- population %>%
     select(year, coa_name, refugees, asylum_seekers)
germany_data <- desired_variables %>%
     filter(coa_name == "Germany")
summary_germany <- germany_data %>%
     group_by(year) %>%
     summarize(
         total_refugees = sum(refugees, na.rm = TRUE),
         total_asylum_seekers = sum(asylum_seekers, na.rm = TRUE),
         .groups = 'drop'
    )

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(summary_germany, aes(x = year)) +
     geom_line(aes(y = total_refugees, color = "Refugees"), size = 1) +
     geom_line(aes(y = total_asylum_seekers, color = "Asylum Seekers"), size = 1) +
     labs(
         title = "Total Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Germany by Year",
         x = "Year",
         y = "Count",
         color = "Legend"
     ) +
     theme_minimal()








Sources:
Data Science Learning Community (2024). Tidy Tuesday: A weekly social data project. https://tidytues.day
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2023/2023-08-22

Data from UNHCR’s annual statistical activities dating back to 1951.
Data from the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA), specifically for registered Palestine refugees under UNRWA’s mandate.
Data from the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) on people displaced within their country due to conflict or violence

title: Project 2
text:
library(tidytuesdayR)
library(dplyr)
library(stringr)
library(ggplot2)

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2021-04-20')
netflix <- tuesdata$netflix

netflix |>
  group_by(type, rating) |>
  summarize(count = n()) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = rating, y = count)) + 
    geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
    labs(x = "Media Type", y = "Count", title = "Types of Media") +
    facet_wrap(~ type)








These graphs convey the number of movies and TV shows for each rating.

clean_genres <- str_remove_all(netflix$listed_in, ",.*") 

This function eliminates the cross-listing of genres to make for an easier analysis.

sum(str_detect(netflix$country, "Singapore|China|India|South Korea|Indonesia|Japan|Taiwan|Philippines") & !is.na(netflix$country))

[1] 1877


I am curious how much Netflix content comes from Asian production. str_detect lets us know that 1877 of the shows and movies on Netflix are from Asia.
Sources:
This dataset consists of tv shows and movies available on Netflix as of 2019. The dataset is collected from Flixable which is a third-party Netflix search engine.
It was found on the TidyTuesday github; https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2021/2021-04-20
